simpler type, by concentric zones of cells, the number of which bears a
general (though not a constant) ratio to its diameter; these cells are
usually somewhat rectangular in shape and sometimes approach a
square, but are more commonly nearly twice as long in the line of the
radius of the disk <s>,</s> as they are in the transverse direction, <s>and have</s> their long sides being parallel to each other. We shall
hereafter see, however, that the form of the superficial cells is very
subject to variation; and that it may be very dissimilar even in different
zones of the same disk (<s>Sect.</s> §§ 48-52). The pores at the margin of the
disk are disposed, as in the simpler type, between the projections formed
by the convexities of the cells; and each is usually surrounded by
the projecting annulus formerly noticed (§ 19). The disposition of
these pores, however, is far from regular, as they seldom form <s>rows</s> rows
that seem exactly continuous with each other, either horizontally or
vertically; and the number of pores in each vertical row is by no
means constant even in different parts of the margin of the same disk. <u>Note</u> [In following the
description of the internal structure of this type of Orbitolite, it will be convenient
for the reader to make frequent reference to the ideal representation which
has been built up in <s>(</s> Plate III, Fig 1), by the combination of materials
furnished by a great number of preparations which are represented in
